name: Kepler-203
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-203 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-203 is a star with 1.1239999999999997 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.11 times its radius. It is located 2340.92 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-203 is known to have 3 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-203 b

Kepler-203 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.04 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 3.16 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-203.

The mass of Kepler-203 b is 9.24 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-203 b is 2.57 that of Earth. At 9.24 Earth masses, Kepler-203 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-203 c

Kepler-203 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.06 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 5.37 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-203.

The mass of Kepler-203 c is 8.39 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-203 c is 2.47 that of Earth. At 8.39 Earth masses, Kepler-203 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-203 d

Kepler-203 d was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.10 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 11.33 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-203.

The mass of Kepler-203 d is 2.29 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-203 d is 1.44 that of Earth. At 2.29 Earth masses, Kepler-203 d is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-203, which contains 3 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
